item.title: How I Started Changing Habits 12 Years Ago ‚Äî and What I Learned Along the Way
item.description: A decade of small choices that reshaped my health from the inside out.
item.content:encoded:
About 12 years ago I began a process that didn‚Äôt look dramatic from the outside, but changed my life from the inside. It wasn‚Äôt one ‚Äúmoment of awakening,‚Äù but a series of small, consistent decisions that kept adding up. I realized something simple: I didn‚Äôt lack information ‚Äî I lacked daily practice.

The first things that left‚Äã

Gradually, not all at once, I removed:

  • üö≠ Cigarettes
  • üç≠ Processed sugar
  • üçî Processed food
  • üåø Cannabis

Not out of struggle, but out of listening. I noticed how my body responded, how my energy shifted, how my mind cleared.

Healing that didn‚Äôt come from a pill‚Äã

Over the years I dealt with:

  • Recurring sports injuries
  • Hormonal imbalance
  • Fatigue that wouldn‚Äôt go away

Instead of chasing a quick fix, I started asking: How do I sleep? How do I eat? How do I train? How do I recover?

Through smart movement, simple nutrition, reducing unnecessary load, and listening to my body ‚Äî real healing began. Not magic. A process.

The current station: alcohol‚Äã

In recent years another step was added to the journey ‚Äî a gradual reduction of alcohol. The deeper I learn, the clearer it becomes that even small amounts of alcohol:

  • Disrupt the gut microbiome
  • Affect white matter in the brain
  • Load the liver
  • Impact recovery, sleep, and overall balance

I‚Äôm not saying I‚Äôll never drink wine. I do enjoy wine. But today the choice is conscious, minimal, and not automatic.

What really changed?‚Äã

The biggest thing I learned is this: Real change doesn‚Äôt start with what you stop ‚Äî it starts with what you build in its place.

More presence. More connection to the body. More honesty with yourself.

And it‚Äôs a process. Even after 12 years ‚Äî it‚Äôs still ongoing.

item.title: Light, Sleep, and Recovery Rituals
item.description: Small light habits that deepen sleep and improve recovery.
item.content:encoded:
Your sleep system is light-driven. When light is right, hormones follow.

Morning‚Äã

  • 5‚Äì10 minutes of outdoor light within an hour of waking.
  • Keep caffeine for after your first light exposure.

Evening‚Äã

  • Dim overhead lights 2 hours before bed.
  • Use warm lamps and avoid bright screens.

Night‚Äã

  • Keep the room cool and dark.
  • If you wake, use low red light only.

If you want help dialing this in, I can build a simple light map for your home.

item.title: Training for the Long Game: Strength + Aerobic Base
item.description: Build a body that lasts by pairing strength with easy aerobic work.
item.content:encoded:
Longevity training is not extreme training. It is repeatable, joint-friendly, and still powerful.

Two anchors‚Äã

  1. Strength: 2‚Äì3 full-body sessions per week.
  2. Aerobic base: 2‚Äì4 sessions of easy, nasal-breathing cardio.

What this builds‚Äã

  • Muscle as metabolic armor
  • Mitochondrial density and stamina
  • Faster recovery between life stressors

If you want a start, try two strength days and two 30-minute zone-2 sessions for three weeks.

item.title: Fasting Rhythms: A 7-Day Cycle You Can Repeat
item.description: A weekly template that balances metabolic flexibility with performance.
item.content:encoded:
Fasting is a tool, not a religion. The goal is flexibility: the ability to burn fat, use glucose, and recover well.

A simple weekly rhythm‚Äã

  • Mon‚ÄìThu: 14‚Äì16 hour overnight fasts, protein-forward first meal.
  • Fri: Early dinner, gentle 12-hour fast to protect sleep.
  • Sat: Fuel for sport or training; no intentional fast.
  • Sun: Optional 18‚Äì20 hour reset if energy and mood feel steady.

Notes‚Äã

  • Hydrate with minerals during longer fasts.
  • Keep training intensity lower on longer fast days.
  • Refeed with protein, fiber, and whole-food carbs.

If this feels good for two weeks, we can personalize with biomarkers and training load.

item.title: The Biohacking Compass: Earth, Sun, Forest, Water
item.description: A simple framework to guide daily decisions for long, healthy living.
item.content:encoded:
Biohacking works best when it is grounded. I use a simple compass that mirrors nature: earth, sun, forest, and water. Each element points to a daily practice that keeps health simple and sustainable.

Earth: foundations‚Äã

Strong sleep, consistent meals, and stable energy are the bedrock. If anything feels off, we reset here first.

Sun: timing‚Äã

Light tells every cell in your body what time it is. Morning sunlight, evening dimming, and movement outdoors create effortless alignment.

Forest: adaptation‚Äã

The forest is diverse and resilient. We train the same way by rotating modalities: strength, aerobic base, mobility, and skill.

Water: recovery‚Äã

Hydration, minerals, breathwork, and cold exposure are the recovery river. When the water flows, stress drains.

If you want a simple start, pick one action from each element and repeat for a week. Your body will tell you what to keep.
